<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 73, 96, 90]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 73, 546, 91]]<|/det|> A student investigates the balancing of a metre rule. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 103, 386, 121]]<|/det|> Fig. 1.1 shows the arrangement. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[109, 133, 878, 288]]<|/det|> <|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 304, 532, 323]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 336, 144, 354]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 336, 918, 400]]<|/det|> The student places the metre rule on the pivot at the \(50.0 \text{cm}\) mark. He places an object Q on the metre rule with its centre at the \(90.0 \text{cm}\) mark. He places a load of weight \(P = 2.0 \text{N}\) on the metre rule and adjusts the position of the load so that the metre rule is as near as possible to being balanced. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 413, 710, 432]]<|/det|> He measures the distance \(x\) from the centre of the load to the pivot. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 445, 918, 478]]<|/det|> He repeats the procedure using loads of weight \(P = 3.0 \text{N}, 4.0 \text{N}, 5.0 \text{N}\) and \(6.0 \text{N}\). All the values of \(P\) and \(x\) are recorded in Table 1.1. <|ref|>table_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[455, 490, 539, 508]]<|/det|> Table 1.1 <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[292, 521, 702, 708]]<|/det|>
\(P/\mathrm {N}\)\(x/\mathrm {cm}\)\(\frac {1}{x}/\frac {1}{\mathrm {cm}}\)
2.040.0
3.027.0
4.020.0
5.015.9
6.013.3
<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 734, 576, 757]]<|/det|> Calculate, and record in Table 1.1, the values of \(\frac{1}{x}\). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 737, 920, 755]]<|/det|> [2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 71, 920, 107]]<|/det|>
The student disconnects the voltmeter. She connects lamp \(\mathsf{L}_2\) in series with lamp \(\mathsf{L}_1\). She connects the voltmeter across lamp \(\mathsf{L}_2\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 117, 885, 138]]<|/det|>
She measures the current \(I_{2}\) in the circuit and the potential difference \(V_{2}\) across lamp \(\mathsf{L}_{2}\).

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[571, 144, 917, 165]]<|/det|>
\[I_{2} = \frac{0.30\mathrm{A}}{V_{2}} = \frac{1.7\mathrm{V}}{V_{2}}.\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 207, 824, 235]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[566, 280, 917, 298]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 312, 920, 348]]<|/det|>
The student disconnects the voltmeter. She connects lamp \(\mathsf{L}_3\) in series with lamps \(\mathsf{L}_1\) and \(\mathsf{L}_2\). She connects the voltmeter across lamp \(\mathsf{L}_3\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 358, 885, 378]]<|/det|>
She measures the current \(I_{3}\) in the circuit and the potential difference \(V_{3}\) across lamp \(\mathsf{L}_{3}\).

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[571, 384, 917, 406]]<|/det|>
\[I_{3} = \frac{0.26\mathrm{A}}{V_{3}} = \frac{1.2\mathrm{V}}{V_{3}}.\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 448, 824, 476]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[566, 521, 917, 541]]<|/det|>
<form>R_{3} = \dots \dots \dots \dots \dots \dots \dots \dots \dots \dots \dots \dots \dots \dots \dots \quad [1]

\[R_{1} + R_{2} + R_{3} = \dots \dots \dots \dots \dots \dots \dots \dots \dots \dots \dots \dots \dots \dots \quad [1]\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 675, 732, 693]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 705, 606, 725]]<|/det|>
Suggestion **A**: \(R_{1} + R_{2} + R_{3}\) should be equal to \(3 \times R_{1}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 737, 616, 756]]<|/det|>
Suggestion **B**: \(R_{1} + R_{2} + R_{3}\) should be less than \(3 \times R_{1}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 768, 640, 787]]<|/det|>
Suggestion **C**: \(R_{1} + R_{2} + R_{3}\) should be greater than \(3 \times R_{1}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 798, 920, 833]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 647, 920, 695]]<|/det|>
State whether your readings show that the image formed in a plane mirror is the same distance behind the mirror as the object is in front of the mirror. Justify your statement by reference to the readings.

statement ............................................................................................................................

<label>(e)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 817, 920, 850]]<|/det|>
The student carries out this experiment with care. Suggest a practical reason why the results may not be accurate.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[881, 895, 920, 913]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[833, 926, 920, 943]]<|/det|>
<mark>[Total: 11]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 73, 94, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>4</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 920, 121]]<|/det|>
A student investigates the effect of the colour of the surface of a metal container on the rate of loss of heat from the container. She knows that black surfaces are better radiators of thermal energy than white surfaces and wants to investigate the effect of other colours.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 134, 420, 152]]<|/det|>
The following apparatus is available:

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 165, 693, 183]]<|/det|>
metal containers each with the outer surface painted a different colour

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 181, 245, 196]]<|/det|>
a thermometer

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 196, 228, 212]]<|/det|>
a stop-watch

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 212, 297, 228]]<|/det|>
a supply of hot water.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 242, 910, 259]]<|/det|>
She can also use other apparatus and materials that are usually available in a school laboratory.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 273, 920, 305]]<|/det|>
